It is probably safe to say that networks would be better off without NAT, ..."

â   â
Although not a serious security solution in itself, the lack of full bidirectional connectivity can be regarded in some situations as a feature rather than a limitation (colloquially called a "natural firewall"). To the extent that NAT depends on a machine on the local network to initiate any connection to hosts on the other side of the router, it prevents malicious activity initiated by outside hosts from reaching those local hosts. However, the same benefit can be achieved with a firewall implementation on the routing device.
